subtitle.Text: Karla: Most of the bookshelves in the house are filled with undifferentiated books, I mean, they’re not undifferentiated but they’re low detail, because, god,

it would be an entire dev cycle’s worth of work to actually do plausible spines on every single book - that would kill us. And then to repeat a whole bunch of books would also be sort of terrible and not be very plausible.
So we had chiefly unlabeled books, or books in which the labels had been rubbed off due to age, etc, and we had a few individual books that were more precisely and specifically named.
Steve: The way that we did the books in the game is we made like, three or four of these clumps of books that have the generic spines on them, they’re just sort of filler books,
they’re kind of like what would be in the bookshelves of a lawyer’s office in a cheap lawyer’s TV commercial -
Karla: Right, where they buy them by the foot and whatever.

Steve: Yeah. And then we took one or two clumps and retextured them to all have specific, readable spines on them and then I just took those clumps and broke them up and scattered the individual books around
in different bookshelves in the house so that hopefully, I think, every bookshelf has a least one unique book in it though that might not be true of everything in the library
since there’s so many bookshelves there, but I guess I should say, every or almost every bookcase had a least one unique book in it that never repeated to kind of split the difference of,

okay they’re not all generic, but also we can’t afford to make them all unique and we didn’t want to have any repeat in an obvious way, so that was our strategy for trying to not do any of the things that we wanted to not do.
